subNodes.conversationText: This one is not going to yield as easily as the first one did. Old locks sometimes dislike modern lockpicks, but I don't even see a lock. I wonder how long this door's been hiding here unopened?
Many, many years, I'd say.  Probably since the days when there was no town, and the only thing that stood on this crag was Swordskeep.
[Running your fingers across the door, you realize that the words of a poem have been engraved into its surface.]
Look.  There are verses carved into the door.
Yes.  I can make them out.  It's a poem--it seems familiar to me, but I can't recall where I've seen it before.  It's--it's quite beautiful.
[You read the verses and record them in your journal.]
I wonder if Uncle Asterchord could tell us more about the poem or this door?  He knows more about Drawn Swords than anybody.
Clearly this is a riddle of some sort, but we'll need to do some investigating before we can figure out how it opens the door.  The trouble is that it doesn't read very much like a riddle at all.
Our investigation will have to be covert.  We do not want all of Drawn Swords to know that we plan to plunder the town's buried treasures.
[Ianth snorts, but she keeps studying the door with great interest.]
It's true that I like a fine poetic mystery myself.  But it is also true that we should not dally here among the dead for too much longer.  Lead on, <FirstName>!
Let's look into the matter soon.  For now it seems there's little else to do here.
Perhaps we ought to forget about this door altogether.  We have other concerns.
You are free to forget about the door, , but that doesn't mean I'm going to. Perhaps one night after you've dozed off at the Sword and Dragon--
Let's see what we can do about getting this open.
<color=green>[Bard/Lore] This is no riddle--at least on the surface.  I recognize it.  This is from "The Falcon and the Dove," an anonymous old ballad.
I should have realized you would recognize it. Good work. Now, how will knowing that get us in?
Let's leave it alone for now.
Too long a time for you, no doubt.
[Running your fingers across the door, you realize that the words of a poem have been engraved into its surface.]
Look.  There are verses carved into the door.
Yes.  I can make them out.  It's a poem--it seems familiar to me, but I can't recall where I've seen it before.  It's--it's quite beautiful.
